Award.AwardTitle: Netshape Gradient Aerogel Articles Reinforced By Hybrid Molecules and Polymers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research bridges the gap between manufacturing capability of current technology and the need to manufacture flexible, netshape gradient silica aerogel articles. Potential uses for these porous gel materials include insulation for cryogenic fuel tanks, for example, or filtration media for removal of particulates or volatile organic compounds from air. The fundamental mechanisms of aerogel reinforcement by hybrid molecules and conformal coating of polymer crosslinks are investigated with the ultimate aim to manufacture stronger silica aerogel articles with negligible changes in density and porosity and strong control of hydrophobicity. This research utilizes a novel method for homogeneous reinforcement of aerogels using chemical reactions between small, optimal quantities of molecularly mixed, very small (approximately 1 nanometer) size hybrid organic-inorganic molecules or silane-endcapped polyurethanes with the silica particles. The research also develops a new ?one-pot? manufacturing method for aerogel articles of complicated shapes; the steps of gelation, chemical reinforcement, and drying are all carried out sequentially in the same mold to dramatically reduce the manufacturing time.

The results of this research are expected to yield understanding of manufacturing of complex shapes of mesoporous, netshape aerogel specimens with gradients of density, porosity and surface energy. Given the large investment in research on aerogels and significant development of understanding of chemistry of aerogel reinforcement in batch processes over the past decade, this systematic program dissecting the source of structure and property generation in aerogel system will benefit a wide range of scientists and engineers in the field. It is anticipated that several derivatives of the proposed research work will be soon developed by other researchers to accommodate inorganic aerogels derived from alumina or organic aerogels derived from polymeric sources. Several outreach functions will be carried out in this research to attract minority and female students to STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerogels are extremely light, 90-95% porous solids filled with air with pore diameter between 2-200 nm. For reference, the diameter of human hair is typically 100,000 nm.  Such materials are excellent thermal insulators, as air molecules are stuck in such small pores and cannot transport heat by any other means than by contact with the neighboring molecules.  Such materials offer thermal insulation in space shuttles and under the sea pipelines, among other things. Apart from thermal insulation, the pore structures in aerogels are attractive in filtration of airborne nanoparticles of diameter 10-150 nm. For reference, there is no commercial technology that can remove airborne nanoparticles as small as 50 nm. Despite such potential, aerogels are rarely used in air filtration as the solid networks that form such aerogels are fragile and most aerogel materials are useless due to their poor mechanical integrity. This work considered several means of mechanical reinforcement of silica and polymer aerogels and developed aerogel articles of netshape, such as those shown in Figure 1 for applications in removal of airborne nanoparticles of diameter smaller than 150 nm.

Several fundamental research activities were pursued. First, commercially available small silane molecules containing substantial fraction of aliphatic hydrocarbon side chains were used to reinforce silica aerogels and to rendered them hydrophobic.  For reference, silica aerogels are inherently hydrophilic, attract water, and instantly collapse upon contacting water, as shown in Figure 2(a). The silica aerogels reinforced via this work showed strong hydrophobic behavior as they can float on water or can hold water droplets on their surfaces without collapse, as evident from Figure 2(b) and 2(c).  Second, polymer chains with multiple reaction points were successfully used to reinforce silica aerogels without changing much the pore structures or the density. In one embodiment, superhydrophobic aerogels with contact angle greater than 150º were created. Third, the mechanically reinforced aerogels were used in removing 25-150 nm size airborne sodium chloride nanoparticles from air stream at 20 liter per minute air flow rate with close to 100% efficiency.  The last results provide tools in the hands of materials scientists to combat air pollution, specifically caused by tiny aerosol particles that are smaller than 100 nm in size and may contain carcinogens or viruses.

The fundamental information generated in this work will be of much interest to researchers working on molecular reinforcement of crosslinked networks or in chromatographic separation of various size molecules. The grant trained four Ph.D. students, two high school researchers who later sought admission in engineering programs, and two undergraduate students who later entered into Ph.D. programs at U.S. universities. The research results were diseminated by the PI in more than 10 keynote talks at international conferences and via 6 peer-reviewed publications in high impact journals. Four more peer-reviewed publications are pending.  The work received considerable interests from industrial organizations in the U.S., especially for development of filters and cleansing tools.
